Posts.Content: I'm just checkin in to see how you're doing.  I've recently been diagnosed with breast cancer, and have a bilateral mastectomy scheduled for next week.  I am Positive for Estrogen and Progesterone receptors, Neg HER2.  I will be 65 next month, and after reading about the meds so many are miserable on, I don't know if I want to deal with them.  I feel fine right now.  Its hard to believe there is this disease inside of me.  I know there will be the surgery recovery to deal with, but whatever I have left of life, it would be good to have quality.  So many of the medications seem to be pretty awful at creating pain and suffering.  I know I'll have to deal with doctors, but this site is quite the education, and I'm learning so much.  Just wanted to touch base after your message from April of 2014.  Thank you for any insight you can offer at this point.
Posts.Title: Side Effects From Aromasin

Posts.Content: Hooray for you!!!!  I'm so glad it was negative!!! Laurie
Posts.Title: Nipple itch

Posts.Content: I had an ultrasound with needle biopsy last Monday.  Tuesday received the call that I have Mucinous Adenocarcinoma.  Will be seeing a general surgeon this Wednesday, the 20th.  Anyone out there with this particular diagnosis?  I called the physician's office last week to see if there were any preliminary tests that I should have prior to the office visit, and they said no.  Seems like a PET scan or something to give an idea as to what else there might be before scheduling a surgery.  Any ideas out there?  This is new to me, as it was to all of you in the beginning.  Just went down a different road and lost my husband to Glioblastoma Multiform this past July. Thank you for any insite that you can give me.
Posts.Title: Mucinous Adenocarcinoma

Posts.Content: I'm sorry you're having a rough time.  I hope someone who's had this done responds and gives you some positive input.  I'm on the schedule to have those procedures done Feb 10th.  Laurie
Posts.Title: Pain still 17 days post bilateral mastectomy, n reconstruction

Posts.Content: I'm so glad to hear that!  Please let us know the biopsy result.  Laurie
Posts.Title: Nipple itch

Posts.Content: I have a friend with similar symptoms, and biopsy results indicated Paget's Disease.  I'm not familiar with that, but am going to look it up.  It seems to be a type of cancer, even with negative mammos, and she's just recently had surgery.  Best wishes to you.  When you get the results, if need be, your doc will refer you to whatever is needed. Positive thoughts heading your way.  Laurie
Posts.Title: Nipple itch

Posts.Content: Thank you.  I really appreciate that.  I will definitely be checking back on this site.  Lots of information.  Read alot of comments on the hormone treatments last night.  Holy cow!  I feel really good right now, and I know I'll have to recover from the surgery, but I don't know if I want to bite into having my bones, joints and muscles hurting as bad as so many folks describe.  I'm glad you got your tubes out.  You sound like you feel better!  Yayyy!
Posts.Title: Pain still 17 days post bilateral mastectomy, n reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Lesley. I'm 65, and my name is Laurie.  First of all, you seem to have your ducks in a row, however, wait until you get the result before you even think of panicking.  I found a lump at Christmastime, and had the needle biopsy, which showed "mucinous adenocarcinoma".  I was given the option of lumpectomy, after which I would have to at least have 6 weeks of radiation, or mastectomy, either one or both breasts.  I chose bilateral mastectomy, with reconstruction and implants at the same time.  The doctors didn't push one way or the other.  It was my choice.  My sentinel node biopsies (they check the lymph nodes while doing the other surgery, and they can find out right away whether they're a problem or not) were all negative.  They also sent a portion of my tumor to a reference lab that did what they call "oncotype", and that gives a numerical rating as to what your risk my be for recurring cancer.  Mine was low, which was great.  To shorten this a bit, what I'm getting at is the fact that the results may not be as terrible as what we automatically think.  I did not have to have radiation or chemo.  I feel great, and with my low risk of recurrence, I chose not to do the hormone treatment that they recommend when your pathology comes back showing estrogen receptor positive.  I read so many messages regarding women feeling fairly terrible while taking these, so that again was my choice.  Because I feel good right now, I don't want to take something that has fairly often caused women to feel bad.  Like you, dealing with your husband who sounds like his cancer is terminal, I lost my husband last July from Glioblastoma Grade 4, a very aggressive, fast growing brain cancer.  He had surgery, then radiation and chemo, and was with me exactly one year from the day of diagnosis.  This may slant my feelings about treatment, but because his brain cancer kept growing, I can't attribute any pain or illness he had to the treatment.  I just know that life is fleeting, and quality is important to what we have of it.  Don't worry.  You will deal with this the best way for you, but wait until you have all the facts before making decisions.  Love yourself and your husband, to death.  Then choose what route you take.  Please keep us posted as to what is happening.  Take care of you.  Laurie
Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed with Breast Cancer.

Posts.Content: What is the screening process for breast cancer once you've had a bilateral mastectomy?
